The Institute is not actively involved in policy discussion and formulation process due to its poor institutional linkages with Government line ministries and other think-tanks.

comment.narrative: 1.1 The Draft Water Code is revised and submitted to the Government for approval. 2.1 The Support Center to support sustainability of billing system is operational and equipment is transferred. 3.1 Project proposal on national water program is prepared.

1.1 No progress during reporting period due to absence of feedback from the Government 2.1 Fully achieved. Final workshop involving all stakeholders devoted to launching of the Support Center is conducted on 29 January and the Center has started its activity. Billing software and IT equipment and specific equipment operation have been transferred to the Suvokova WSS Company. Monitoring of the Support Center created under PACDE showed positive changes in water supply services. The collection rate have been increased on 2,2 times (55 mln sum vs 125 mln average per month). This happens due to transparent accounting, so consumers confident with fair collection of their money and satisfaction with increased service efficiency. The efficiency of water supply service to more that 73000 people of Karmana district of Navoi region has been improved. 3.1 The workplan with additional budget required for preparatory assistance is approved by senior management. The recruitment of an international consultant is finalized. The mission agenda of the consultant is approved by UNDP and coordinated with project partners (EU and GIZ). The EU project proposal (DoA) is elaborated and accepted by EU. Agreement between UNDP and EU is signed.

Enhancing the capacity in the area of reforms focused on achieving greater effectiveness, accountability and transparency of the budget preparation system.
Enhancing the capacity in the area of reforms focused on achieving greater effectiveness, accountability and transparency of the budget preparation system.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1. The legislative framework does not meet the realities of changes taking place within the budget reform and does not reflect the conceptual changes introduced into the budget practice. Given this situation, the Government recognizes the need to improve the legislative framework for successful implementation of budget reforms. 2. With UNDP’s assistance under the framework of the "Public Finance Reform in Uzbekistan" project the conceptual approaches and guidelines were developed for the introduction of PBB, thereby creating a platform for reforming the budget process based on the new approaches. 3. Practice shows that the transparency and efficiency of public procurement procedures need improvement. Ensuring the effectiveness of public procurement system necessitates the revisiting and improvement of fragmented and sometimes contradictory legislative framework of public procurement. 4. Ensuring the sustainability of local budgets, improving efficiency and targeting of their expenditures is the essential aspect of the budget system reform. The analysis of preparation, execution and monitoring of local budgets shows that the use of automatic balancing mechanisms of local budgets not always leads to horizontal equity of expenditures and undermines the incentives of local authorities to expand the revenue base. 5.At the piloting stage of the individual elements of PBB and medium-term planning, and subsequently in expanding their application, the re-training of specialists of the regional branches of the Ministry of Finance, line ministries /budget recipients, as well as the extensive training of managers of budget programs, who should be proficient in PBB methodology, will be required. This necessitates the establishment of comprehensive training base, including training programs and modules, as well as the development of training capacity Of the training center under the Ministry of Finance.

1.1 Recommendations on introduction of changes and amendments to the Budget Code based on its practical approbation during 2 years discussed, consolidated and submitted to the Government. 1.3 Itemized Commentary to the Budget code finalized and published at the website of the Ministry of Finance 1.5 Guidelines on implementation of NPSAS that comply with IPSAS developed and discussed 3.1 Draft Law on “Public Procurement” is finalized, approved by the Government and submitted to the Parliament. 3.3 Strategic note on implementation of Green Public procurement in Uzbekistan developed and discussed with stakeholders 5.7.1 At least 25 Deputies of Oliy Maljis (with 30% female trainees) learned new changes made to the legislation by the Budget Code. 5.7.2 At least 50 public sector specialists (with 30% female trainees) learned the NPSAS-related changes made to public sector accounting and reporting system 5.7.3 At least 30 public sector specialists (with 30% male trainees) learned the gender-budgeting methodology and application of gender-sensitive indicators 5.8 At least 30 civil society representatives (with 30% female trainees) learned the basics of budgetary process and legislative novelties introduced by the budget reform.

1.1 Under the support of the project recommendations on introduction of changes to the Budget code based on the results of the 1st year approbation period provided by the academic community and other stakeholders have been summarized and submitted to the Ministry of Finance. On 18 June 2015 those recommendations have been discussed during the Round table conducted at the Legislative Chamber of Oliy Majlis (within the Parliamentary group “Milliy Tiklanish”). During 2015 the project continued to facilitate a broad discussion of the Budget code within its 2-years approbation. The results of approbation have been discussed during the round table conducted on 27 November 2015 with participation of 50 experts (including 42 males and 8 females) from key stakeholders including the government agencies, academic community, lawyers and etc. The final results on 2 years approbation have been summarized and submitted to the Ministry of Finance.
http://www.publicfinance.uz/en/cluster_news/1847/
1.3 The draft Itemized Commentary to the Budget code have been developed and forwarded to interested parties for comments and feedback. Further the document was translated into the Uzbek language and submitted to the Ministry of Finance. Upon finalization it is planned to publish it at the website of the Ministry of Finance in Russian and Uzbek languages.
1.5 Methodological guideline on implementation of Budget accounting standards has been developed and submitted to the Ministry of Finance. Additionally the project conducted a number of thematic workshops on this topic for the trainees of the Training center.
3.1 In close cooperation with national partners the project facilitated further discussion of the draft Law “On public procurement” (PPL). Under the support of the project a number of working discussions with key stakeholders have been conducted. Currently the draft PPL has been finalized and submitted to the Ministry of Finance. comment.narrative:
1.1 38 government officials (7 women) represented the State Committee for Nature Protection, State Customs Committee, Ministry of Higher and Secondary Specialized Education, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Justice and others were involved in regional and national level activities on implementation of nationally adopted HCFC phase-out strategy, in particular national round table, during which implementation of Montreal Protocol in Uzbekistan, including enforcing national and international legislations on phase out ODSs (particularly HCFC) organized on 16th September 2016 in Tashkent to enable its effective implementation.
Evidence: Reports by government officials and international experts.
1.2 6 (2 women) high-level officials from Uzbekistan participated events of networking with non-Art 5 and other Art 5 countries dedicated to strengthening international cooperation on Montreal Protocol, including (i) HCFC Phase-out regional Project Board Meeting in July 2015 in Istanbul; (ii) in the resumed 36th Meeting of the Open-Ended Working Group of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer and in 27th Meeting of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol in October 2015 in Dubai; (iii) in the Thematic meeting on HPMP in October 2015 in Minsk, and (iv) study tour on ODS destruction and application of ODS-free technologies to China in December 2015. Within the study tour Uzbekistan representatives familiarized with the application of free-ODS technologies, including natural refrigerants and ODSs disposal. Further development of cooperation in the field of Montreal Protocol agreed with the Ministry of Environment Protection and UNDP of China.

1.2. [2] knowledge products are prepared on “Beekeeping practices in Karakalpakstan” and “Sustainable use of land and water resources”. Those products are being printed for further dissemination among the partners/beneficiaries. As part of the activities on promoting the best-practices in the field of agriculture, the project has conducted field trainings for [30] farmers of the Shomanay and Kanlikul district on lazer leveling to expand this practice. Also, the experience of the project has been shared with the new UNDP project funded by the Adaptation Fund for further possible replication and scale up of the lazer leveling method.
[3] advocacy events took place through regional TV showcasing the best- practices of the project in the areas of application the lazer leveling as a tool for rational use of water and land resources.
1.3. As a result of the business review committee held within the frame of the project, [10] new small scale business projects established covering three types of business 1) production of embroidered goods; 2) production of dolls-souvenirs; 3) production of shell-made souvenirs in Muynak district. All [10] beneficiaries of those initiated projects are women/girls of rural communities from Muynak district.
- Nurjaybaeva Mirikhan is one of the beneficiaries of the UN joint project from Tikozek community of the Muynak district. As she indicates “participation in the 3 days workshop on making shell made souvenirs organized by project in cooperation with UNWOMEN in 2014 was life changing event in her life”. Since then, through the support of the project, she received necessary start up support to launch her own household level business on making the shell made souvenirs. She states that ‘as sea has gone I used to think how to use those shells that are a lot now in former seashore’ and ‘thanks to support of the project now finally I have skills to use them and make income’. Within a one year time, Mirikhan has already participated in number of
1.1. [2] new demonstration plots - small and medium scale business projects on bee farming development established.

comment.narrative:
1. Some replications of the GEF SGP demonstrated best resource use practices takes place by the initiative of the farmers or communities. Local administrations are not involved in wide replication of the technologies and practices 2. No trainings are made for governmental officials. All information sharing takes place either through personal contacts or distribution of information by post 3. Only 2 issues of the newsletter where analytical papers from the GEF SGP projects collected are published and distributed for the past 4 years of experience. 4. Business is hardly involved in replication and up scaling of the demonstrated practices. Further widening of their participation is needed 5. Zero model business plans are developed for demonstrated technologies. Further replication of the technologies and practices is hindered by limitations for self-financing of the replications or borrowing funds from financial institutions 6. Replication of the best resource use technologies and practices is hindered by limitations for self-financing of the replications or borrowing funds from financial institutions.
To put in line with new UNDP corporate Strategic Plan IRRF indicators, the project change the wording of the project indicators, baseline and targets. The newly stated indicators do not change the essence of the project work but rather generalize and paraphrase the results. The baseline for the newly stated indicators are:
• 1.1.3.A1: Number of demonstration schemes which expand and diversify the productive base based on the use of sustainable production technologies – 14 by the beginning of 2014 • 1.1.3.A2: Number of advocacy and knowledge schemes which expand and diversify the productive base based on the use of sustainable production technologies – 4 by the beginning of 2014

1.1. At least 5 new rural districts where local governing administration has supported adoption and replication of best resource use practices demonstrated by the GEF SGP in other regions and/or neighbouring districts 1.2. At least 25 governmental officials (local, regional or national) exposed to trainings and experience sharing on GEF SGP demonstrated resource management practices 1.3. At least 5 advocacy and knowledge schemes which expand and diversify the productive base based on the use of sustainable production technologies initiated 2.1. At least 2 new businesses and households from rural and urban areas engaged in production processes of best resource use practices/technologies demonstrated by the GEF SGP 2.2. At least 5 demonstration schemes which expand and diversify the productive base based on the use of sustainable production technologies initiated

1.1. Currently at least 16 rural districts are on track of replicating previously demonstrated by the GEF SGP best resource use practices, including:
- 13 districts in Surkhandarya province have started working on laser leveling techniques; - 71 districts that will be engaged in laser leveling as a result of discount distribution of laser leveling equipment under Chirchik machinery project; - 2 new districts (Pop and Uch Kurgan) in Namangan province have started using equipment laser leveling as a result of Namangan project; - 2 districts where drip irrigation have been replicated. - At least 1 district in Kashkadarya province (Chirokchi district), Arrabandi village where the drip irrigation from Namangan will be used
1.2. The trainings and engagement of governmental officials has been hindered because of various administrative barriers. Exposure will be kept through analytical publications. Potential trainings through Center of business and farmers.
1.3. The following advocacy and knowledge schemes which will expand and diversify the productive base based on the use of sustainable production technologies have been implemented:
- campaign on no tillage practice through 2 projects in Khorezm and Fergana - campaing on laser leveling through project on machinery (Chirchik) and Namangan and Karakalpakstan - campaign on mycro hydro power stations - campaign on UZV and sadki aquaculture; - campaign on pistachio, almond – Tashkent and Chirokchi provinces - campaign on desert reforestation through Surkhan project
2.1. At least 10 new businesses and households from rural and urban areas engaged in production processes of best resource use practices/technologies demonstrated by the GEF SGP, including 4 business on aquaculture 4 business on pistachio in Tashkent province 2 business on drip irrigation
2.2. At least 6 demonstration schemes which expand and diversify the productive base based on the use of sustainable production technologies initiated
Bio lab in Nama

description.narrative: The project objective is to develop climate resilience of farming and pastoral communities in the drought prone parts of Uzbekistan, specifically Karakalpakstan
The project aims at developing climate resilience of farming and pastoral communities in the drought prone parts of Uzbekistan, specifically Karakalpakstan

1.1 # of automated meteo stations and monitoring equipment for field data collection and transmission 1.2 Coverage of hydro-meteorological observation network on km2 1.3 Lead time (weeks) for drought early warning 1.4.1 # of Field School/Extension services delivering training in adaptation practices to farmers and pastoralists 1.4.2 % Dekhkan farmers (including % of female Dekhkan farmers) receiving extension services to introduce farm-based climate risk management measures 2.1 # of dekhkan farmers (% of women) adopted conservation agriculture practices (e.g. low till, mixed cropping, fodder production, and residue crop soil) 2.2 # of dekhkan farmers (% of women) adopted water saving irrigation practices (e.g. land levelling, furrow and drip irrigation systems) 2.3 # of Dekhans established horticulture greenhouses and # of female lead ones 2.4 # of legal acts and regulations enacted to support well tested farm-based adaptation measures 3.1 # of ha with saksaul and tamarix plantations to deliver sand stabilization and soil desalinization function 3.2 # of Dekhkan farmer and pastoral community members (% of women) involved in landscape level adaptation measures (e.g. saksaul and tamarix planting) through local employment programme 3.3 # of cooperatives established at Khokimiyat and Makhalla levels for community management of sand stabilizing plantations 4.1 # of documented good practices (bulletins) of agronomic and water saving measures 4.2 # of lessons learned bulletins disseminated through printed and web-based media 4.3 # of farm and pasture land demonstration meetings covered by media and attended by national and local authorities 5.1 Monitoring and Evaluation system is in place 5.2 Project outputs and outcomes evaluated at mid and final points of project implementation cycle, and lessons learned codified

comment.narrative: 1.1 Density of meteorological and hydrological stations is insufficient to provide adequate coverage for drought monitoring 1.2 Lack of data (insufficient coverage) to adequately monitor climate and water supply status 1.3 Warning systems are not linked with water user and farmer groups; and drought early warning is not effectively and timely delivered 1.4 No extension services for climate change adaptation by farmers in place 2.1 Low awareness of dekhkan farmers on adaptation solutions to optimize agricultural production and minimize the adverse impacts of droughts both in short and long term 2.2 Low awareness of dekhkan farmers on water saving irrigation practices 2.3 Limited use of horticulture greenhouses as drought mitigation solutions 2.4 Insufficient legal and regulatory framework to support well-tested farm-based adaptation measures 3.1 Insufficient coverage of landscape level adaptation measures (plantations) for sand stabilization and moisture retention 3.2 Low involvement of dekhkan farmers and pastoral community in landscape level adaptation measures 3.3 Lack of institutional mechanisms for community management of sand stabilizing plantations 4.1 Some water saving irrigation and agronomic methods were sporadically demonstrated but farmers continue inefficient and unsustainable practices that increase their vulnerability to drought and climate change risks 4.2 Lessons learned are not being captured for broader sharing to address an aggravation of the food security situation during the droughts and as a result of climate change 4.3 Outreach mechanism, transmission of knowledge is limited in scope (within the scientific community), not well tailored or systematic 5.1 No Monitoring and Evaluation system 5.2 No evaluation of project output and outcomes

Target 1
1.1 Locations of 8 automated meteo stations and hydrological monitoring equipment identified; and equipment to automate those 8 and 2 Doppler water meters for 2 hydro meteorological posts procured
1.2 Technical requirements for IT equipment of automated hydro-meteorological observation network developed and IT equipment procured (20 low capability computers, 10 high capability computers, including 2 high capability server)
1.3 Drought early warning mechanisms elaborated and its locations identified
1.4 Concept of establishing science-based extension services for subsistence dekhan and farmers developed
Target 2
2.1 At least 5,000 stakeholders (30% of women) provided with printing and publications associated with the climate resilient conservation agriculture practices
2.2 At least 5,000 stakeholders (30% of women) trained in application of land leveling, furrow, siphon and drip irrigation systems
2.3 16,000 households (50% of women) trained in horticulture greenhouse establishing
Target 3
3.1 Technical assistance in best practices on development of management plan for sand stabilization and soil desalinization and comprehensive landscape rehabilitation provided at least 5,000 ha of lands
3.2 At least one community management scheme for planting and maintenance as community employment scheme for landscape level adaptation developed
3.3 At least 5,000 (20% of women) stakeholders are aware of best practices and provided with technical assistance in establishing cooperative management system for landscape rehabilitation and management to enhance community control and ownership
Target 4
4.3 At least 2 farm and pasture land demonstration meetings with participation of national, local authorities, media and communities, and associated printing and publications produced and disseminated

comment.narrative: Baseline 1.1 Low capacities of MEC technical staff in data collection and analysis. Baseline 1.2 Lack of mechanisms for data collection and analysis. description.narrative: Project aims to promote more effective, accountable and inclusive local governance in Uzbekistan by enhancing local government’s performance, increasing citizen participation in local governance, encouraging increased accountability and transparency.
Local Governance Support Programme: Participation and Partnership/ Phase #2
Accountability - local government finance

Indicators: 1.1. Central decision-makers are provided with concept note on empowerment of women in civil service 1.2. Curriculum development at the Academy of Public Administration, extended to local governments 2.2. Number of documented tools on performance of public oversight, representative and rulemaking functions fulfilled by Kengash in cooperation with local stakeholders 3.1.Number of initiatives taken by local authorities on additional revenue generation in collaboration with local stakeholders

comment.narrative: Baselines: 1.1. Lack of national strategy for representation of women among civil servants at the local level 1.2. In the absence of civil service reform, few opportunities for local civil servants to improve performance Baselines: 2.2. Kengash has limited capacity to effectively carry out its oversight, representative and rule-making functions in partnership with local stakeholders 3.1. Highly centralized fiscal and public finance management does not motivate local governments to seek for additional sources of local revenue generation for equitable development

1. The developed roadmap and methodology for functional review of public services provision are tested to integrate into multi-channel local service delivery mechanisms. 2. The quality of curriculum development of the Academy of Public Administration is enhanced through participatory design processes and the introduction of new courses (at least 2 new courses) for the civil servants of local governments, and for Master’s students. 3. E-government tools are applied in ensuring the openness of local governments. 4. A cross practice Local Development Strategy for cities is developed through consultative processes, and tested and used by local administration for planning purposes. 5. Policy options for the new Budget Code on empowering local governments to improve the quality of financial management, and to increase local revenue generation, are prepared and submitted to pilot regional khokimyiats and Cabinet of Ministers. 6. Regular (public consultations with local stakeholders are conducted in accordance with annual plan of local governments 7. A plan of actions of pilot Kengashes level (Tashkent region) is adopted and implemented in order to perform oversight, representative and rulemaking functions. 8. A Concept note of the Law on Local Government Authorities elaborated and discussed

Period: January 1- June 26, 2015 1. Interagency Coordination Working Group (IACWG) has discussed and endorsed a Concept note of Roadmap and methodology for Functional Review (FR) of public services provision on November 20, 2014. Tashkent regional khokimiyat/administration was defined as a pilot to conduct FR. Using international best practices as well as results of parallel initiative on functional review of Ministry of Labour and Social Protection, UNDP has developed the first draft of the Methodology of FR in the regional khokimiyat and shared it with national partners for discussion. Methodology and final report on FR will be discussed with experts and regional authorities before submitting them to IACWG meeting in November 2015. FR will contribute to raise efficiency of public administration on local level in accordance with the Concept note on further deepening of democratic reforms and forming of civil society in the country, initiated by the President of Uzbekistan. FR is performed in accordance with President’s Decree #F-3863 from June 26, 2012 on reforming and increasing efficiency of the public administration system аs well as UNDAF outcome 4. The results of FR will be used in drafting new version of Law on local government authorities. Evidence: - Minutes of IACWG meeting; - Decision of the Head of IACWG; 2. The Government has adopted a decision on further improving the system of training for public officials in Uzbekistan (presidential decree #4435) on 10 April 2012, which envisages introduction of modern innovative and practical courses for APA students. The courses on "Corporate Management", "Regional Development" and "E-government" are currently being developed within the framework of UNDP and APA joint action plan for 2015 and will be included into the curriculum of APA from September 2015. Before that feedbacks on developed courses will be received from other UNDP projects (ex. E-gov, and etc.). Also two textbooks "Foundations of civil societ

1. The developed roadmap and methodology for functional review of public services provision are tested to integrate into multi-channel local service delivery mechanisms.
2. The quality of curriculum development of the Academy of Public Administration is enhanced through participatory design processes and the introduction of new courses (at least 2 new courses) for the civil servants of local governments, and for Master’s students.
3. The proposed amendments to the Law ‘On Local Government’ are submitted to the Cabinet of Ministers.
4. E-government tools are applied in ensuring the openness of local governments.
5. A cross practice Local Development Strategy for cities is developed through consultative processes, and tested and used by local administration for planning purposes.
6. Policy options for the new Budget Code on empowering local governments to improve the quality of financial management, and to increase local revenue generation, are prepared and submitted to pilot regional khokimyiats and Cabinet of Ministers.
7. Regular (public consultations with local stakeholders are conducted in accordance with annual plan of local governments
8. A plan of actions of pilot Kengashes level (Tashkent region) is adopted and implemented in order to perform oversight, representative and rulemaking functions.

description.narrative: 1.1.availability of transactional services through single interactive public services portal (my.gov.uz); 1.2. Availability of draft legislative acts on e-Government, and Open Government Data. 2.1. Availability of research & analytical papers, manuals, and policy briefs on introduction & application of inter-operability and BPR mechanisms 2.2. Availability of methodology to undertake inventory of public services 2.3. Availability of technical requirements for Business Process Management System for Single interactive public services portal 3.1. Enhanced capacity of the e-Government development center on strategic decision making through strategic & technical support. 3.2. Policy dialogue on e-Government development progress in Uzbekistan. 3.3. Availability of M&E mechanisms to benchmark the progress of ICT implementation in government organizations.

comment.narrative:
1.1. Majority of the introduced online (interactive) services in my.gov.uz are still of informative nature, only 6% of online services in my.gov.uz allow e-payment options 1.2. Lack of legislation/normative framework on e-Government and Open Data in line with international best practices.
2:Existing information systems of state organizations cannot properly “talk to each other” (interoperate), thus, there is a high need for introduction of common policies & principles for back-office processes and inter-agency communication, as well as redesign of business processes. While developing the policies (on interoperability and BPR) international best practices and lessons learned should be reviewed and analyzed. Baseline 3: New requirements of e-Government evolution and major updates of relevant national priorities in Uzbekistan require corresponding changes in institutional arrangements and increase of capacity of e-Government support institutions to ensure timely and effective strategic & technical support in implementation of e-Government strategy.

1.1. Roadmap, Action plan on Call Center and draft outreach Plan for my.gov.uz is submitted to CCITT for consideration. 1.2. International expertise, including through partnership with UNDESA, is provided to the draft normative legal acts on e-government and open data. 2.1. At least 2 research papers on interoperability and BPR are prepared and widely disseminated based on pilot application of BPR methodology in selected government organizations; 2.2. The definition of public services, guidelines for classification and inventory of public services are submitted to Government for streamling public services in 8 ministries and agencies as well as for legislative review and drafting. 3.1. Communication strategy for e-governance is developed and disseminated. 3.2. Current M&E system on e-government is revised and widely discussed. 3.3. Revised M&E system is applied online to benchmark progress of the ICT implementation in government organizations.

1.1. The Call Center for my.gov.uz (accessible via # 1060) has processed some 27,500 applications (7% of total) since its launch in July 2013. Action plan on enhancing and streamlining operation of the Call Center have been submitted to the E-Government Development Center (EDC) for consideration. E-Government Outreach Plan to promote e-government and online public services has been developed and submitted to Ministry of Information Technologies and Communications (MITC) for adoption. Also a profile of the E-Government page on Facebook has been created as part of the e-gov communication strategy (http://www.fb.com/egovernmentuz). The main purpose of the profile is to stimulate e-participation and attract more FB users to the E-gov page, hence to share knowledge on the recent news on e-services and information related to e-government. The newly created profile has collected 63% more Likes for the E-gov page in the first 12 hours following its launch. 1.2. Consultations on enhancing the national legislation on e-governance, public services and open data were held in April 2015 with the experts from the UNDESA, R.Kerby and V.Cherkasov. Their recommendations were summed up and included in the Minutes №4 of the “Interagency Working Group on improving the sub-index Online Services in the ranking of e-government” meeting held on May 6, 2015. Joint work done with the MITC and EDC on: - drafting the Law on Electronic Government signed by the President on December 9, 2015. The law stipulates the establishment and proper functioning of the e-government framework, including integrated and interoperable information systems and centralized databases, to provide quality public services to citizens and businesses. - elaborating the Cabinet of Ministers Resolution “On the measures to further improve procedures for public service delivery and interagency information sharing” adopted on May 13, 2015. - drafting the Cabinet of Ministers resolution on Open Data Portal adopted on August 7

1.1. At least two transactional online services are available via my.gov.uz and/or other channels. 1.2. Normative legal act (or government’s technical standard) is drafted to institutionalize BPR in modernization of public services delivery. 2.2. description.narrative: The objective is to improve effectiveness of aid flowing into Uzbekistan and strengthen capacities of the Government institutions in better coordination, management and mobilization of external resources at country and sector levels.

Improved effectiveness of aid flowing into Uzbekistan in the long-term perspective and strengthened capacities of the relevant Government institutions in better coordination, management and mobilization of external resources at country and sector levels.

1.1. Partnership Agreement (PA) between the Government and Development Partners (DP) exists/available. 1.2. Policies and Government decrees to enhance aid effectiveness adopted. 1.3. Results framework focusing on a list of key priorities developed in a participatory manner. 1.4. Paris declaration indicators (PDI) customized for Uzbekistan. 1.5. Number of PDI surveys conducted. 2.1. Number of sectors developing project portfolios with results orientation based on the roadmaps and action plans. 2.2. Number of sectors with harmonized set of indicators for joint monitoring. 2.3. A pilot sector-wide approach implemented and evaluated. 2.4. Number of joint M&E activities leading to assessment of achieved results. 3.1. AIMS developed and operational. 3.2. Detailed and up to date development assistance information is available at/through AIMS. 3.3. Number of bulletins with summary information on aid and analytical reports published.

comment.narrative: Baseline 1.1. There is no formal agreement between the Government and development partners establishing the principles and framework of aid effectiveness agenda. Baseline 1.2. Lack of policies and Government decrees on aid effectiveness. Baseline 1.3. There is no official document outlining medium to long term development strategy and priorities at national level, which hampers results based programming and monitoring of development assistance. Baseline 1.4. Uzbekistan is not a signatory to Paris Declaration on Aid effectiveness, and has not endorsed aid effectiveness principles. Baseline 1.5. No aid effectiveness surveys were conducted in the country, and there is no practice and methodology on evaluation of value-for-money properties of aid flows. Baseline 2.1. Most of the sectors lack results-orientation in developing their project portfolios and do not have development roadmaps. Baseline 2.2. No sectors with harmonized set of indicators for joint monitoring. Baseline 2.3. Sector approaches are not used at all. Baseline 2.4. No joint M&E activities aiming at assessment of achieved results conducted. Baseline 3.1. The existing Excel based database does not have many of the features of similar systems supporting decisions and analytical work on aid, used in more than 50 aid recipient countries. Baseline 3.2. Unavailability of comprehensive and updated aid related information results in lack of transparency and awareness in making informed decisions. Baseline 3.3. No summary and analytical information is published.

1.1.1. Partnership Agreement between Government and Development Partners (DP) developed and endorsed. 1.1.2. Government-DP forums established/rehabilitated and operational. 1.2.1. Government’s communication policy on external aid targeted to development results developed and put into operation. 1.3.1. Results framework developed to facilitate participatory planning and M&E. 1.2.3. Guidelines developed on integration of external aid flows with domestic budget to avoid duplication and to strengthen participatory planning of development interventions. 1.4.1. Indicators of aid effectiveness defined/customized and used for assessments. 1.5.1. TOR was developed by the Project and adopted by newly established sector working groups as a constituent document, which indicates a requirem

Current legislative drafting process and monitoring of legislation do not have mechanism and procedures to check Bills for compliance with international legal commitments and applying international best practices. 1.2.1. Although MoJ, line ministries/state authorities play significant role in drafting new legislation, the quality of draft laws and regulations is not consistently high. 1.2.2. No unified database of signed international agreements and treaties

New Rules of procedures for international compliance review of Bills/laws institutionalized in IMCL through adoption of regulation. 3.National legislation which regulates legal drafting process is amended to include the mechanism for participatory compliance review for conformity with international standards and best practices; at least 2 draft laws or regulations developed and tested according to the new Rules of procedure. 4. The lack of Rules of procedures to involve individual experts and NGOs in legislative process and taking into account public opinion does not encourage MPs to exercise their legislative drafting functions in transparent, accountable and participatory manner.

1. Expert rosters created for selected committees in order to use in organization of public consultations. 2. MPs piloted and reported publicly regarding at least 4 pilot public consultations with involvement of technical experts and concerned CSOs.

1.Support in quality lawmaking of Parliament, including: - Draft Law on Public oversight and Draft Law on Parliamentary control which were submitted to Legislative chamber of Oliy Majlis; - Draft Law “On Amendments and Additions to the Law on normative legal acts" (submitted to the Legislative chamber of Oliy Majlis); - Guidelines on conduction of impact assessment of draft laws, affecting the entrepreneurship (submitted to the Legislative chamber of Oliy Majlis). 2. Support to Parliament and government in boosting of public consultations of new laws and regulations through assistance in launching and enhancement of public consultations platform on Unified Portal of Interactive Public Services and www.regulation.gov.uz web-site. As a result, in 2015, 284 draft laws and regulations, affecting entrepreneurship were posted on Portal, 535 comments and suggetions from citizens and experts were received and considered. This has resulted in enhancing the quality of laws and strengthening citizen and businesses participation in lawmaking, and will facilitate to reduce burdensome regulations for businesses and citizens.
3. Assistance the Parliament and government in enhancement of International treaties implementation process, by support of activity of interagency working group, providing quality international expertise and drafting new methodologies for inventory of international treaties. These will result in institutionalization of monitoring tool for implementation of international treaties and creation of unified database for collection and tracking of all international agreements and treaties of Uzbekistan.

1. Official websites of both Chambers launched special functionalities to allow users to comment on draft laws online and publish MPs reports on results of public discussions. 2. Draft Rules of procedures to involve individual experts and CSOs is developed and submitted to both Chambers of Oliy Majlis.

Improving quality of social service delivery for persons with disabilities and lonely elderly people in Uzbekistan.
Accountability - local government finance

Lack of transparency and absence of rapid evidence based control mechanisms in delivery of social benefits and social services for elderly lonely and PWDs 2.1. Absence of of gate-keeping system and case management in social protection for lonely elderly and PwD within MLSPP system 2.2. No feedback mechanism on quality of social services for lonely elderly and PWD 2.3. No training courses for MLSPP staff on social protection and social work with lonely elderly and PWD (need assessment will be stemming from functional review exercise) 2.4. 1.1.1. Functional review report and concept note on the organizational reform of the Ministry prepared; 1.1.4. Legislative act on structural reform of MLSPP prepared; 1.1.5. New positions of social workers created within the MLSPP structure as per recommendations of the functional review; Vertical functional review of Ministry of Labour and Social Protection of Population (MLSPP) was conducted for the first time in Uzbekistan, draft report was developed by Int.Consultant N.Rava in consultations with the management of MLSPP, President Office, Cabinet of Ministers, Ministries of Economy, Finance, Health, Public education, Higher and Secondary Professional Education, UNDP personnel and SCOs. One of facts revealed by the report was that the ratio of PWDs to MLSPP specialists is 284. Results of the report will be used for formulating clear vision on the mandate, roles and functions of MLSPP, creation of a new more effective and efficient structure of MLSPP in line with governmental priorities. The Resolutions of The President and Cabinet of Ministers on structural changes in the ministry will be developed till the end of the year and will result in improving quality of public service delivery for more than 4 mln. elderly, 600 thousands of people with disabilities and 600 thousands of unemployed people. New positions for 105 social workers, lawyers, psychologists were established with additional allocations from state budget 1005,9 UZS annually. New positions for more than 200 social workers in social services of MLSPP, Ministry of Health and Public Education will be created after adoption of the draft Law “On social services.” The functional review serves as an example for other UNDP projects, including LGSP, which has started the functional review of local khokimiyats. 1.2.1. description.narrative: 1.1. Availability of research mechanism for survey of public’s satisfaction level of courts’ activities. 1.2. Percent of judges and court staff, trained on issues of Ethics Code of judges adoption. 1.3. Availability of Communications Strategy on increasing awareness of public, society and media about courts’ activities. 1.4. Availability of Concept on mechanisms to provide free legal aid during civil cases. 1.5. Number of proposals on further support of judicial reforms, developed with the participation of representatives of expert community, lawyers and international donor organizations and submitted for consideration to Supreme court of the Republic of Uzbekistan. 1.6. Availability of amendments to normative legal act on enforcement of court decisions with a view to ensure effectiveness of bailiffs’ activities. 2.1. Number of practical manuals and new courses on actual issues of civil justice for judges, court staff and the public. 2.2. Availability of draft strategy for continuous education of civil courts and judicial staff designed and submitted to national partners for consideration. 2.3. Availability of draft qualifications requirements to the civil court secretaries formulated and submitted to Supreme Court and other beneficiaries. 2.4. Availability of methodological framework for application of international conventions in courts. 3.1. Availability of normative framework to allow parties to the commercial disputes enjoying the benefits of system of audio-video recording during litigation and appeal process.

comment.narrative: 1.1. Institutional feedback mechanisms for citizens are needed further improvement. 1.2. Ethics Code of judges, developed and approved in 2013, is not accessible for wider public and needed supplementary regulation on procedural issues. 1.3. Enhancement of legislation of the Republic of Uzbekistan in the area of government transparency and accessibility of information about public authority activities, as well as the principle of trial publicity, require from court system development of strategic and regulating documents, aimed at further improvement of situation in this area and increasing public trust. 1.4. Now existing mechanisms of providing free legal aid are implemented in the framework of criminal justice and not applied to civil courts. 1.5. Experts community, lawyers, advocates, international donor organizations, representatives of public and other stakeholders are not involved in discussion of realization of judicial reforms and development of proposals for their further improvement and enhancement. 1.6. Enforcement of court rulings is a cornerstone, influencing on the level of public trust in courts. According to Decree of President of the Republic of Uzbekistan # ПП-722 dated 01.11.2007, on results of nine months of 2007 about 20% enforcement orders have not been enforced and about 25% enforcement orders have been enforced with missed deadlines, fixed by legislation. This fact is attributed with both high workload of enforcement officers, and gaps in legislation regulating enforcement process. 2.1. Mechanisms of professional development of judges and court staff, including development of their professional and technical skills, are needed further enhancement. 2.2. Despite there is national legislation on legal education, however, continuous legal education of practitioners is fragmented throughout different agency-based training institutions. A comprehensive agenda setting is this regard is needed. 2.3. Acting judges and court staff are not enough invol

1.Concept of supplementary mechanism of registration of complaints and petitions from citizens is developed and submitted to Supreme Court. This Concept will also include a methodology on surveying of trial participants’ satisfaction on court performance; 2.At least 10 policy proposals on further intensive implementation of judicial reforms with the participation of representatives of expert community, lawyers and international donor organizations have been developed and submitted for consideration to Supreme court. 3. 1 analytical paper on issues of further enhancement of procedural legislation has been prepared. 4. Additional module of “E-SUD” information system for courts of appeal instance has been developed. 5. Equipment for audio and video recording in economical courts has been procured and installed.

Period: January 1 - December 31, 2015. 1. Concept of supplementary mechanism of registration of complaints and petitions from citizens is developed and submitted to Supreme Court. This Concept will also include a methodology on surveying of trial participants’ satisfaction on court performance; Project researched the existing mechanisms and instruments of registration of complaints and petitions from citizens in the courts. As it comes out, Supreme court does not have any mature system of registration and systematization as well as analysis of the submitted complaints and petitions. In order to develop alternative (improved) mechanisms project researched international practice. Besides that Project worked on the concept of survey of trial participants’ satisfaction on court performance. After conduction of survey and based on the report on international practice the recommendation to the Supreme court will be submitted.
2. At least 10 policy proposals on further intensive implementation of judicial reforms with the participation of representatives of expert community, lawyers and international donor organizations have been developed and submitted for consideration to Supreme court. Project prepared the draft of local act of Supreme Court regulating usage of E-SUD e-justice system by courts. The draft has been successfully adopted by the resolution of the Presidium of the Supreme Court and thus gave first legal basis for usage of e-justice system. Project has also prepared a draft of law introducing informational technologies into the civil litigation. Research center under the Supreme Court drafted alternative draft of the law taking into account Projects draft and project specialist’s comments. As the result, the law # ЗРУ-388 has been adopted by the Parliament on 09.06.2015. The law creates legal basis for filing civil cases though internet thus creating more convenience for people, especially for vulnerable people who cannot leave their premises to visit court h
